glyph.d: M1,0 h2 v2 h-2 z M1,6 h2 v2 h-2 z

text.tspan: Naturally the trumps includes a
card for the Devil—like the Pope and
Death, for the mediaeval European,
the Devil was a fact of life, and
the recurring villain in any number
of folk tales and hearthside
stories. Nevertheless the depiction
of devils makes some people nervous.
In more modern decks, this card is
sometimes replaced with a picture of
the Horned Man, a pagan god of
fertility and nature—even though the
interpretation of the card remains
broadly the same.
The Devil card represents anger and
resentment, and being trapped in a
bad situation that you cannot escape
(like the figures chained to the
Devil’s plinth).
In my version of the card I omitted
the plinth, so the chains of the the
two figures at the bottom of the
card are held by the devil himself.
